commentBody: Lovely puzzle.  Solid clues. Breezy for a Saturday, but I really enjoyed it.
I had LeoTardBAR before shortly correcting it due to the crosses. Now I wish they were an actual thing, would be fun to see!

Slightly embarrassed Tolkien fan who mentally ran the gamut from Nazg√ªl to Samwise and Baggins to frodo and even came up with Gollum before remembering Gollum‚Äôs original name SMEAGOL. Otherwise fun puzzle

Was this fresh but easy? Sassy but so-so? 
Was the trivia obscure enough?
Were the words wordy enough?
Were the clues cluey enough?
I'm not sure I can tell these days.

Is there no Midi for Saturday because the Mini is bigger, or was it just not there when I logged on but it's there now?

Will this comment post? Do I care?

Did anyone else find this easy for a Saturday? I finished it in 10 minutes and 54 seconds on two glasses of wine, demolishing my Saturday record by well over a minute. (My average hovers around 30 minutes for Sat.) Maybe I just got lucky with the clues this time?

I finished this one fairly quickly, although it never felt easy. As an LOTR nerd, I was surprised to be puzzled by ringbearer.  I tried Samwise and then Baggins and then Isildur, before letting the crosses lead me to SM√âAGOL. Only at the end did I catch the little joke that the next across clue was ‚Äúprecious person.‚Äù  For the non-LOTR crowd, SM√âAGOL always referred to the ring as his precioussss.

REEFS for school rooms was a nice touch.

"Do you walk all that way for pancakes?"
"No, IHOP!"

("Batter get moving then!")

I think that I‚Äôm happy! 20:37 feels good for this one. SW and SE took some feeling into. The last couple of days have been challenging fun puzzles to do. Thank you. Let‚Äôs keep it going on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays. Please.

I think I accidentally stumbled on a way to make any puzzle much, much harder.

You can do it by entering things like Bff for 20A, which poisoned two long downs for way too long.

You can do it by putting "hojo" in for 48, forgetting orange was their color (wasn't it?), hopelessly complicating the lower left.

On the other hand, I utterly surprised myself by coming up with  35D [Acting like a sore loser, informally].  How did both the actual answer and a similar ending in "sore" get into my brain?

49A, NTH, is exactly the kind of answer that used to utterly topple me.  Now I enter it without giving it much thought.

Please allow me the reverie of taking a mind's eye trip to NAIAD, the tiny moon of Neptune which is barreling along just barely over the top of Neptune's clouds.

Naiad is only about 30,000 miles from Neptune (compare the 240,000 mile distance between the earth and the moon), and the view of the planet from it must be one of the most awe-inspiring views in the entire solar system.The massive and gorgeous blue Neptune taking up a stunning amount of Naiad's sky.  

I hope to visit there one day.
Filled and clued like Highlights magazine. Since this is the Saturday standard now, not really seeing any point in renewing a very long subscription
Oh i did this one a little too fast it seems

So ea_y. We're back to this no_se_se on Saturdays, after a very respectable and redeeming Thursday and Friday?

Please st_p. Edito_s, please. You're pol_uti_g your own product. I didn't even like the fill here. F_h.

(3rd round past the emu, which seems to prefer ransom notes)

Before pivoting my career to manufacturing life-sized cardboard cutouts of Ted Danson, I worked in a LEATHER BAR briefly after college. It was an edifying experience for two reasons: 1) the owner kept a 26 volume set of the Encyclopedia Britannica behind the bar which I read avidly in my spare time, and 2) I was listening to an audio CD of lectures on the Civil War that summer.  The one thing I never understood was why General Grant failed to entrench his troops prior to the surprise attack at the Battle of Shiloh. It seems to me that a wartime leader and strategist of his intellect and experience would have had the foresight to avoid such a costly blunder.  It‚Äôs salient questions like this about our nation‚Äôs darkest era, which will always remind me of the smell of leather and the sound of The Village People blaring through a PA system.

I don‚Äôt have much energy to rail about difficulty level again, really, so let‚Äôs just frame this as a puzzle of missed opportunities. If as Caitlin says the six long entries are nearly all fresh and debuts, then why not clue them in a fresh amusing way? Of the six the only one that‚Äôs even remotely imaginative was the clue for STRESSLEVEL, which I liked, but by that time I had so many crosses I didn‚Äôt even have to puzzle that one out. Really, there were no possibilities of any misdirecting or clever clues for INSTANTTAN, ERASERPEN, LEATHERBAR? That‚Äôs a shame because this was an artfully constructed grid with a lot of potential.

Like others it did take me awhile to suss out SM√âAGOL especially since I had FEATHERBAR first, but really isn‚Äôt this another missed opportunity? You have ‚ÄúPrecious person‚Äù as a clue right across from it, how do you not clue that one as ‚Äú‚ÄòPrecious‚Äô person?‚Äù

Meanwhile there‚Äôs the litany of gimmes on a Saturday again. NEMEAN? SERB for Tesla? ARIEL? LICE? I guess I do have a little energy to complain about difficulty.

Oh well. I did get to hear Francis‚Äôs reverie about NAIAD which perked me up, and I learned a fun fact about FDR.

I can not believe BU__HURT made the puzzle.  I know it refers to spanking.  But I know it is used in other contexts as well.  

Color me shocked. 
I guess I found this a bit easier than I would expect for a Saturday. But not by much. 

As is the unexplained case for many of my solves. The symmetrical NW and SE filled themselves in, in less than 5 minutes. But NE and SW, especially NE, gave me fits.

I am never going to remember AAVE. I get it‚Äôs a language model. And I definitely ‚Äúdon‚Äôt speak good‚Äù when with friends. But in formal settings, it‚Äôs asking for judgement.  At least that‚Äôs what me and my friends be thinking.

A while back (not too long ago but I‚Äôve never been good with time) this grid design elicited a comment likening the shape to a swastika.

As a member of the tribe and (aspiring) reasonable person I found the comparison ridiculous and I only bring it up now to lightly paraphrase the words of a famous psychologist and fellow member:

_‚ÄúSometimes a puzzle is just a puzzle‚Äù_

Let us appreciate the construction for what it is while acknowledging the limits of the art form. Who are you? Who am I? Am I rambling now? Perhaps, but it‚Äôs late and I will begrudgingly join the dark side and admit the puzzles have indeed (maybe just maybe) gotten easier.

Oh well, to the first week of June of 1982 I go!

userLocation: Spring Hill, just south of Armageddon
commentBody:
Rebound week spoiled by an utterly mediocre Saturday.

As usual, kudos to the setter and catcalls to the editors.

Had i been presented with the completed puzzle and asked for my thoughts, I'd have replied:  Dang that's some chewy fill.  Now let's design some worthy clues.

What went through these editors' heads, I wonder.

Akshually, the Blues Brothers didn't wear fedoras, they wore pork pie hats. According to the liner notes for Briefcase Full of Blues, at least (which I bought when it came out when I was in high school, and probably still have in my long-neglected LP collection).
It's neat because it's a Saturday grid, but a Tuesday difficulty, so you get a little something for everyone.

Maybe it‚Äôs just the acute bronchitis slowing down my brain as well as my body (second time this year! Are they just putting saline in the vaccines now?) but I found this rather challenging. I plowed my way through, but not without some hiccups. And coughs. 

Has anyone ever seen an ERASER PEN that actually erases? I haven‚Äôt.

Who else had an image for 36A of braces with curlicue flourishes as a fashion in hipster orthodontia?
We now have the mini, the midi, the (mici) crossword. I propose an additional puzzle - the mega. A deviously difficult daily grid for advanced solvers. Alas, one can dream.

An observation on varying usages. Back last millennium, when I was teaching maths, we had: parentheses - (), brackets - [], and braces - {}. All without further qualification. So I still find CURLY BRACES tautological.
Want some Saturday wordplay? Here's some, it seems el presidente is "bored of peace".
Not seeing the purported midi in the iPhone app. Can anyone help?

Counterpoint to the naysayers: after a 9 course meal with wine pairings and cocktails, this felt like an appropriately difficult (17 minute) Saturday. Sober, I *might* admit that these are getting a tad bit easier. Ask me in the morning, but go easy on the volume given the headache.
the construction was fine how did this get approved for saturday. that took 12 minutes what do i do now
Sm√©agol was tough but it pales  In comparison to aave, yesand & curlybraces. Guess I‚Äôm acting butt hurt üòú
Who knew feather bars weren't a thing? I guess I need to get out more.
Set a PR with this one. I'm sure some will complain it was easy but think I was just on the same wavelength as the creator. So I enjoyed it!

Super fast Saturday (8:46!) but providing us with gold in the comments section.
Note, in my retrograde archive solving yesterday I got to Sunday March 3, 2002, where the clue for 106 across was "type of plane". Same answer as today's 1 down so I was in the mindset from the beginning.
Some clues were too obscure for me like slang for rap pioneers.
So not my wavelength - lookup puzzle. Hopefully Sunday is a good one.
7D is simply wrong. Grover Cleveland said that to Benjamin Harrison. FDR was only 26 years old when Grover Cleveland died. Not sure where you came up with that.
Don't know about "Yes And" but okay.

Weird.  My 7A clue refers to ‚Äúbeer ball‚Äù and not ‚Äúbeer pong‚Äù.  Is beer ball a thing, other than a now hard to find 1/8 of a keg vessel? Made this one much harder than beer pong, which would have been a gimme.  I found this puzzle more challenging than a lot of others, due mostly to the crossing of NEMEAN, NAIAD, and NERFS.  Came in around avg for a Saturday.
Mohair and angora are completely different fibers.

Don‚Äôt understand ‚Äúair horn,‚Äù got all the letters but the ‚Äún‚Äù (I also never heard of the crossword ‚Äúdnd‚Äù so I should have figured it out), but I don‚Äôt understand the clue for ‚Äúair horn.‚Äù

Freshness in the box today.

Not just the obvious freshness of answer debuts, but also many answers I‚Äôve heard of and like but don‚Äôt think about often.  The grid, to me, seemed like it was popping with zing.

I loved the main bones ‚Äì the vertical and horizontal stagger-stacks that centered the grid.  There was the lovely ring of CURLY BRACES, and when I looked it up, I remembered seeing them in the past, and I smiled.  I pictured that LEATHER BAR and that ERASER PEN.  I loved the misdirect of [Pressure gauge], where I was foraging for a name for the little pen-sized tool that measures tire pressure.

And, speaking of NYT answer debuts, five of the six answers of those stacks are just that, and the sixth (INSTANT TAN) only appeared once before in the history of the Times puzzle.

The box, on the whole, just had a feeling of newness from start to finish, that I found rare and wonderful, Adam.  It radiated personality and made for a splendid outing.  Thank you so much for making this!

Fine construction and quite a bit of interesting fill. But, to me, yet another "themeless Wednesday" puzzle. Done in 15 minutes, and I'm by no means a fast solver. 

Didn't know SAMBAR, but LEATHERBAR came very quickly because the clue was too leading. Which seems to be happening quite often now on weekends.

Anyway, a well-made puzzle that I wish would have taken me more time to solve.

This would have been one of my quicker times if I hadn‚Äôt misspelled NEMiAN. Spent forever not seeing my error.
SM√âAGOL a gimme for this LOTR fanatic, the rest was a little hit and miss. Blue roofed restaurant? Grover Cleveland? Allan express? Oof. Thank goodness I could make an educated guess with the crossings. 
LEATHER BAR reminded me of my first bar job as a young, impressionable thing. An eye opener and a half, with not a single story that would pass the emu cordon. Sweet memories of dancing on the bar in wildly inappropriate clothing every time a specific song came on, whose title would also not pass the cordon.  A job requirement I should stress, not from too much sampling of the beverages (which would have got me fired). Happy days. My aging bones wouldn‚Äôt let me hop up there now.
Saturday PB for me. Thrilled to see NEOPETS!

What made me feel old?
Great question. I'd love to tell you.

This puzzle.

What made it sting less?
*Another* great question. 

Seeing the gold star pop up
and getting that *same* feeling I got
in second grade when a spelling test
came back with the tiny plastic version
about 117 years ago.

I was very young when I was introduced to crossword puzzles‚Ä¶first grade‚Ä¶so glad my parents didn‚Äôt have to explain gay dress codes to me‚Ä¶how very awkward. I wonder how parents today would feel about that.

I sensed lots of niche clueing today, some of which I knew from experience (YESAND), some which I knew vicariously (DND), and some of which were totally foreign to me (SMEAGOL, BUTTHURT, LEATHERBAR).

However, I still found it to be an enjoyable puzzle to solve, and I learned stuff.  That‚Äôs why we solve them, right?  To relax and become more enlightened?  And if certain clues aren‚Äôt to your liking, repeat our mantra from St Deb:  ‚ÄúYour mileage may vary‚Äù and move on with your day.

Have a lovely day, be kind, and give yourselves ‚Äî and one another ‚Äî grace.

Saturdays are back !!!

That was a slog for all the right reasons
Got done very quickly. Under 5 minutes.

Yet another Saturday where the clues were far too straightforward. I hesitated to put LICE in 34D, because it just felt too easy. Other clues were just as simple: 10D, 12D, 39A, 52A...

The only spot that tripped me up was the NW, where I had Baggins before SMEAGOL. I saw my mistake pretty quick, though, as the crosses were extremely easy to get.

Sorry if I sound BUTTHURT.

Being BUTT HURT about the crossword‚Äôs difficulty is definitely a FIRST WORLD PROBLEM (has that ever been in a Sunday puzzle?).  In addition to SM√âAGOL/Precious one, I like the crosses of THATSME/IMHERE and LETFLY/SATBY.

Sure, the puzzle was fun, but that golden glow on my star definitely came from a bottle (in which I sniffed clues of the Instant Win variety).
Today I wanted a *beach*, instead.

I certainly felt like a fish out of water, filling this puzzle, or at least most of it.  I did somehow figure out "to whom Grover Cleveland" spake, not very presciently....  I know more about the labors of Hercules than the LOTR characters, and DHubby insists that FRODO had the ring.  
YES, AND what's with 35D???  
"Coral and sand" are tints--pastel tints, IMHO; HUES--shades-- are more muscular colors...At least, that's the way I see them, speaking as someone seriously concerned with colors.  (Here we pause for (redacted) to jump in and disagree even if he doesn't have any crayons or watercolor paints.)

 Quilters do not use "Angora fabric" and it took forever for me to come up with MOHAIR, even though I had a mohair sweater in 10th grade....(back in the "BEFORE TIMES"...)

The rest of the puzzle I got with crossings and guesses.  I do have an ERASER PEN somewhere in my desk, along with dead ballpoint pens, stray paperclips, and refills for my FriXion pen.
What's up with the Midi? I'm getting a message that the page no longer exists. Yes, reporting it via the appropriate email. But, sniff, I was so looking forward to it.

Well... actually a bitzer prized to see that so many found this one unusually easy. Typical tough Saturday workout for me, but was still an enjoyable solve. Just a lot of working the crosses until something dawned on me. And... one answer history search today was for HUE. Wondered about the clue. Well... 114 appearances in the Shortz era and... was clued with a reference to Vietnam... twice. 142 appearances in the pre-Shortz era and was clued to Vietnam (or Annam) 21 times. Hmmm.. And... my puzzle find today. A Wednesday from May 24, 2006 by Adam G. Perl. Three theme answers in that one: First clue was: "Start of a sign in a costume store," and the others clued as "Part 2 of the sign" and "End of the sign." Those answers: PIRATEEARRINGS TWODOLLARSAPAIR ONLYABUCKANEAR Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=5/24/2006&g=50&d=A ....
A good workout for me! Really solid clueing and a satisfying solve.

The Northwest was fun as I tried out various ring wearers from Gandalf to Samwise

Not on the harder side of Saturdays and therefore more fun for me.

A classic example, for me at least, of zipping through and then coming to a grinding halt, this time in the SW.  So set it down for an hour and them came back and, as Emeril would say, "Bam!".  Nice one today.  

I'm still trying to figure out what I think of the Midi but today's was a nice shout out to the home town.
I really thought butt hurt was an offensive term - glad it means something different to most people according to Google.
BUTTHURT is a spanking thing? That‚Äôs news to me! I thought it was kinda messed up and just another poorly aged relic of the golden age of the internet.

I entered JIVE because, well, Mrs. Cleaver in Airplane. BRO because, well, I still don't understand BAE. BATTER over STEREO was painfull. MERCURLEVEL was just dumb on my part. TOPHAT over FEDORA was a palm-plant.

Tough. Nice job, creator. I have multiple handprints on my forehead, but I guess that's what Saturdays are for.

Happy Tolkien fan here. Precioussssss. I saw that LESBIANBAR fit and was mad about the dress code hint. Lesbians don‚Äôt have to wear‚Ä¶ oh ‚Ä¶ LEATHERBAR is the answer.

And, THANK YOU FOR THE MIDI! I love having more crossword puzzles to do.
Yeah, this wasn't great.
Very low stress level with this one. No retyping or eraser pen needed. But def harder than beerball.

A fine puzzle, in my humble opinion.  Well within the Goldilocks-zone for a Saturday.

As I put in the last letter -- the R of AIR HORN -- I was sure I was in for the dreaded "something's amiss" message, because looking up I saw that strange UTTHU grouping of letters, and that couldn't be right, right?

I was surprised to hear the joyful music, and I had to take a second to parse the word(s) at 35-Down as BUTT HURT, a phrase I've never seen before (to the best of my recollection) and couldn't quite understand.

I'm tempted to do a Google search to better understand the phrase, but I'm more than a little nervous about what I might find.
For now, I'll accept Caitlin's explanation of the term in the column and move on.
This one felt like it was made for kids. Which, ok‚Äînew market, get them on board‚Äîbut why is it here on a Saturday?

"Braaaap! Pew pew pew! Enjoy this relaxing, meditative themeless puzzle."

Caitlin could not have predicted how this photo caption captures the contrasts of today.


I did not find this puzzle all that easy, probably a wheelhouse problem in the northeast corner, but I did finish. Not quite the Saturday-tough of before times, maybe Wednesday-plus.
Loved the alignment of the answer for 14 across with the clue for 16 across. Can only be done trying to imitate that voice‚Ä¶.

Solid construction, breezy solve.  Too easy for a Saturday, IMHO.  Didn't necessarily know a bunch of pop-culture stuff -- AAVE, LOLA Tang, NEOPETS, NERFS, even SMEAGOL (my one brush with LOTR was in print, 50 years ago, and that was plenty for me).  But all of it was easy enough to figure out on crosses.  I'd like to think that I'm getting smarter, but honestly, the puzzles are just not as challenging as they used to be.  I miss a good work out with my coffee.
Fun and engaging, enjoyed fully! (Deity of Choice) knows we need the distraction from the noise of the distraction covering the other distraction of the main distraction. Good luck all.
Grover Cleveland knew FDR?! That almost sounds like one of those apocryphal facts from the BEFORE TIMES, like Hercules slaying the lion at the Council of Nicaea.

Just got my personal best for a Saturday on this one.

Some may say it's too easy for a Saturday, but I'm just gonna enjoy feeling good about myself for a bit. Especially since I just got destroyed by an old Sunday from the archive; very humbled by that one.

Nice. It engaged me mentally enough to provide a pleasant distraction from the After Times.

I seemed to remember Cleveland's photos looking as though he was from the robber baron era and thought he might be a little early for FDR. Trying to remember Teddy's middle name provided a little of that distraction.

Came here curious to see how many pale-skinned folks were unfamiliar with the term "ashy." It was in the puzzle not that long ago, but I remember it from friends who would get ashy when I'd turn an unattractive beet red.

I'm thrilled to hit a one year streak today! 

Ive been solving for years, but inevitably blow the streak occasionally, not by using the check function but by messing up on timing when traveling. ü§∑üèº‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏èü§£

Now I will diligently endeavor to do it for another year!

Today's puzzle was a gem; it was a pleasure to meet this milestone on such a clever puzzle.
27 Down is incorrect. As an architectural professional the answer does not match the prompt. The answer is not a detail (no spoilers). Also, there are no such things as blueprints anymore.
46 across is incorrect. Angora comes from rabbits, mohair comes from goats. I had to do the down hints to get that. Rolling my eyes.

A couple of errant entries along the road. FRATBro at 7A, and BiTcHout at 35D. 
Unfortunately in BEFORETIMES, my kids had several encounters with LICE. Just seeing the word still ups my STRESSLEVEL!
Still nursing my owwie hip from Monday's dig out, so not much cleaning today. Did clean out the coal stove and clean up all the ensuing mess. HOPE this is the last fire for this year.

ERASER PEN? Shouldn't it be the PEN ERASER that makes a correction? I never liked those things anyway. If you're going to commit to ink, you need to be all in.

I thought Spirit LEVEL was very clever on my part, as a measure. That and hErOicTIMES made things quite difficult. But it's nice to be challenged on a Saturday.
nice one
I feel like Friday got switched with Saturday!

30% faster than average.  I'll take it considering I was having some trouble with the first letter of 15D (until I tried "L") and having to run the alphabet for the SMEAGOL/OGS cross, which still did not ring a bell after I got it.

Happy to have completed another Saturday, a day which still every now and then reminds me why I don't have a 100% solve rate.
Breathlessness is dyspnea, not apnea
A day late on this one, but I heard y‚Äôall like triple-stacked spanners‚Ä¶ https://www.nytimes.com/crosswords/game/daily/2004/02/14
For whatever reason I initially filled in AUTOPSY rather than AUTOPAY on the basis that there was no other possible option! Going for a walk now!

Oh how I loooooaaaaatttthhhhhhe the phrase at 35 down. Ugh! I refused to fill in until I absolutely had to. I cringe every time anyone says it! Usually on online comment boards, in my life anyhow. First appearance, and hopefully the last! 

Otherwise pleasant enough though very fast. I filled out all the corners first and then the middle, but I did have one error.... Turns out I don't know Lord of the Rings or gay night life spots well enough because SMEAGOf and fEATHERBARS seemed okay. I guess I thought of the f because of Gandalf ending in f.   He and frodo are really the only character names I ever remember.  Or maybe I was thinking of Smirnoff. üç∏ ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è üç∏

Anyhow, happy weekend!!

Absolutely loved this puzzle. It felt young and fresh. For me, it hit that perfect balance of feeling challenging but never frustrating. 
Loved seeing SMEAGOL üòä

In our "before times," my friend Joe D. would regularly take weekend vacations to NYC, with his elderly, widowed mother. After a long day or sight-seeing, Mom would conk out early, and Joe would don some steer hide, and head out to ye Olde Leathere Bars. Once, on one such establishment--the Eagle?--he was refused admittance, as Jode, who otherwise looked the part, was wearing cross-trainers, and not boots.
"What were you thinking?" I asked him.
"Well, I didn't have enough room in my luggage for boots. They were very apologetic--you know how if you go to a fine restaurant, which requires a jacket, but you don't have one, the maitre d' will bring you a jacket to hang over the back of your chair? Well, the doorman brought me a couple pairs of boots to borrow, but none of them fit:-("
This was a really fast Saturday for me, but I liked it. Thanks for the fun!
Today's Headlines? Talk about BUTT HURT! :(
Devilishly clued!

Here‚Äôs another shout out to all you brainiacs. Yesterday, I asked a question about a clue and 4 people answered! Thank you all so much. 

Not really sure I completely get the answer though. LOL
I don‚Äôt ever want to see 35D in a NYT puzzle ever again. What a juvenile, crass phrase, and unworthy of inclusion in the NYT crossword.

My usual late puzzle find. This one a rather remarkable theme. A Wednesday from January 27, 2016 by Adam G. Perl. Six theme answers straightforwardly clued and symmetrically placed around the top and bottom of the puzzle. Only identified as related to the theme because they each had an asterisk at the beginning of the clue. Those answers: SMITE ITEMS MITES EMITS ITSME IMSET And then the reveal was three connected across answers - those placed symmetrically down from left to right across the middle of the puzzle. Those answers: THETIMES THEYARE ACHANGIN Here's that link: https://www.xwordinfo.com/Crossword?date=1/27/2016 ....

Well I just did today‚Äôs LA Times Crossword. It took me ten more minutes than the NYT‚Äôs and it was a lot of fun + very fresh. I really liked it a lot and thanks a lot for recommending it. I just don‚Äôt know if I‚Äôd be like, ‚Äúthe NYT XWP today was all that much easier in comparison.‚Äù I mean, yes you could say it by the time spent.
I confidently filled eInHORn, making SAMBeR & BUTTHUnT, which all made sense since an AIRHORN, IMHO, is the opposite of a ‚Äúmusical sample‚Äùüôâ!
Had to take the blue. After an hour and a half with too many look ups, I had a completed puzzle with no idea where the error or errors were. Lost a 59 day streak, oh well...
Far too easy for a Saturday, in my opinion. 9:09.
One of those Saturdays that feels like a minor miracle when I‚Äôm able to finish with no hints {even though I was just guessing on NEMEAN and CURLYBRACES.}
Trilby, not FEDORA for the Blues Brothers! Smaller brim that turns up in the back. Popular choice of Frank Sinatra.
‚ÄúButthurt‚Äù is an inappropriate phrase which is a gay derogatory put down. Please do better. It is offensive

Perhaps I was the only one who thought  57A could have been WEBKINS. Or were they WEBKINZ?  Darn they were cute .

Fun puzzle though !
Almost didn‚Äôt get this because I didn‚Äôt want to believe they‚Äôd have 35D as an answer. Do better!
LEATHERBARS: In my experience these are generally laid-back spaces that have *customary* dress but not *required* dress.

@T

I had sEeTHruBAR at first‚Äî that dress code would be even more fun!

@T
Actually, it might be tutu much.

@dutchiris
Unless they have a barre.
@dutchiris ah you have a pointe there

@Megan I had heard it but didn‚Äôt know how to spell it until I got LEATHER BAR.
So yes a very good puzzle. I only checked one word to be sure CURLY BRACES was right and then I saw that it was ERASER PEN and not PiN. Perfect for me. Thanks!
@Barry Ancona The Midi wasn‚Äôt there at first, then it was there.
@Barry Ancona Indigestion? üòâ

@Barry Ancona

I'd say so.  I found it to be a solid Saturday 

I finished well under average but felt that I had to make a lot of "educated?" guesses, (ARIEL, NAIAD, BAE, IHOP, ASHY) and knew enough about the Blues Brothers, ETHAN Allen and the Green Mountain Boys, LOTR, and gaming to get enough crosses to complete it without getting stuck for long.

Loved TROY story.

@Barry Ancona The collective says "Very Easy" and this time they're right. https://xwstats.com/puzzles/2026-02-28 Meanwhile the LA Times has published what should have been here. Classically tough puzzle by Zhang and Musa.

@Francis

"Right now"? Don't you mean STAT?

@Nancy J.

I honestly don't know their rhythm.  It really seems to go all over the map, which I'm mostly fine with.  In the recent past it's trended much easier than NYT, but not any more.  I do think they push the difficulty on weekends.

I just searched and the best reference I see is a self-described constructor on Reddit who wrote:

"Mondays are usually the easiest puzzle of the week. They get progressively harder through Saturday. Sundays are usually a mix of Tuesday-Wednesday clues, sometimes a little more difficult based on the theme.
Source: My puzzles are published in the LA Times
frequently. :)  "

@B

Thanks, I think I'll add that to my Saturday routine.
I think this is his way  of saying, "Let's preview all the usual comments here."
@Francis How about the Cryptogram? although maybe there aren‚Äôt enough of them.

userLocation: Back in Jays-town. üê¶ Spring at last!

commentBody:
@Francis

The second sentence of the first paragraph practically demands a "that's what she said."

@Francis

I'm willing to wait for a VR headset and AI videos fed on NASA probe data.  Not sure how tides work in that situation,  

Heck we don't even have colonies on our moon. After Apollo, I'd have bet that that would happen by 2000, 

Space is too big for humans.  Those Ancient Aliens must be something else.  üëΩ

@Al  in Pittsburgh

Apollo.

I never imagined that in my lifetime every single person to have walked on the moon would be dead.

I assumed there would be a steady stream of new moon-walkers, and that humanity would always have at least one living example of a dual-world human.

Alas, no.

Space really probably is too big for us.

But I can sure dream.
@Francis Our solar system is the best one, other stars think they have it but nobody has more soul than our Sol. üíôü©µ

@Matt

Speaking of which, in a way... Yesterday I had an experience straight from the intro to a pr0n flick.

My wife and I recently bought an extremely showy, Italian sports sedan. Yesterday as I left the faculty and headed for the parking lot, I noticed somebody standing by my car. I came nearer and realized it was one of my prettiest students from last year. She broke into a smile.
'I've been waiting here too see who drives this gorgeous thing,' she said.

And the rest is history 

(Of me getting into the car alone and driving home)

commentBody:
@Kaisa

Ah, that old saw...

@Matt

I'm a misanthrope, too, on most days, so we'd get along great!

@Francis

When the moon hits your eye like a huge Costco pizza, that's NAIAD.

@Kaisa

How beautiful!  And Holst was a genius for undertaking such a project as "The Planets".

I used to listen to this while I was programming and trying to avoid the chatter of the office.

I love how it just fades away to absolutely nothing.  A completely evaporating work of music.

@Kaisa

I have a big ol' spot in my heart for Finland, and in fact all the Nordic countries. That really extends to all of northern Europe--Germany, Poland, Estonia, Latvia, Lithuania, the British Isles.

Never seen it (though I've been to central eastern Germany), and though I'd would gladly go to Neptune, I'm not sure if I've got enough energy left for Europe.

On of my cherished friends here in Minnesota, who grew up in Duluth, is of Finnish origins.

@Francis

Just made a quick calculation.

If you were standing on Naiad looking at Neptune, the planet from edge to edge would spanabout 60 degrees.  

If you hold your hand at arm's length, and splay it as much as possible, the angle formed by your eye, your thumb, and your little finger, would cover about 20-25 degrees.  So if you put your other hand touching that hand, and splay that hand out, you'd about 40-50 degrees.

In other works you hands could not hide Neptune at arms length using both your hands.

By comparison, our son and moon is hidden just by a thumb's width at arm's length.

commentBody:
@a
I'm still renewing, but the Saturday puzzles are much easier than they used to be.  I learned a lot by working on tricky Saturday puzzles.  Nowadays, I don't feel that same kind of challenge, and I don't feel like I'm getting much better.
@B I tried making a joke that puzzle constructors were now always cru_cifiedverbalists I‚Äôm this comment board, but that didn‚Äôt go through.

@B

Two hours after release and XWStats has this listed as "Very Easy".  The Times Crossword is engaged in an act of slow public self-immolation.

It.  Is.  Saturday.

:(

@Ace

That paragraph may be the longest and most fascinating verbal journey I've ever read.  Ted Danson, to leather, to Shiloh, back to leather, and finally to the Village People.

@Ace

That has to be one of the best posts on this board, ever.

There was this tiny kebab bar around the corner from the main gate to Warsaw University's central campus. It was nothing special, really, but I really liked the place with its cozy atmosphere, super friendly African owner and his cute Ukrainian wife. I ate there often in my law school days. In fact, I liked it so much I occasionally drove there all the way across Warsaw to have lunch. So one day I'm on my way for my fave kebab, negotiating the capital's chaotic traffic in my beat-up Daewoo Lanos, going way too fast, pop music blaring on the radio. Suddenly the music stops. It's not time for the news but the news people are on. Their voices tremble. "There had just been a horrific attack in New York".

It was September 11, 2001.

The date always reminds me of my fave kebab place.

Ain't it funny how our heads work?

@Andrzej

One of the...I don't know...perks?...of old age is that you collect a growing list of "everyone knows where they were moments".

I guess my earliest was the Kennedy assassination.  The Challenger disaster.  9/11, of course.  I'll risk censure to suggest that Nov. 5, 2024 was a day like that in my mind.

So many other contenders:  the MLK, RFK assassinations.  Three Mile Island.  Chernobyl.

Memories eh. I was at an earthy tea shop once, buzzed on good Darjeeling. Surrounded by a riot of colourful pillows. I had just been in a fancy scents shop, and spritzed this most wondrous spicy amber perfume on my wrists. It really evolved, that scent, I regret never going back to buy it. But I really feel it was special because I only experienced it once. I had such a peculiar feeling of being okay with everything that day. Not in a blunted, apathetic way. I struggle to describe it, but I felt so open and free. Wisps of a pleasant memory from the BEFORE TIMES. Thanks to this thread for reminding me of that moment. I enjoyed reading yours.

@Ace
Yes. This is why I read these comments on crossword puzzles.
@Ace -- I loved your ramble.  More like this, please!

@Francis

Add Jan 6 2021 to that list.

@Francis, I wasn‚Äôt around yet for JFK, and too young for MLK and RFK. But I was for all those others, and I indeed remember exactly where I was and what I was doing in each of those horrible, watershed moments. 

@Andrzej‚Äôs post took me back to that terrible Tuesday morning in 2001 and made me tear up instantly. (And yours reminded me of that other black Tuesday in 2024.)

@Ace
Yes, and‚Ä¶
@Ace These are the kinds of comments I live for.

@Fleur Anne üòÇüòÇüòÇ

@Ace like Anndrej said, this if a hall of fame post.  üëèüèª

userLocation: Back in Jays-town. üê¶ Spring at last!
commentBody:
@Francis
Interesting that everyone named terrible moments. No one mentioned the moon landing? Their first seeing of an eclipse? The first free elections in South Africa? (Still today, seeing the lineups of those voters in my mind's eye makes me tear up.) The fall of the Berlin Wall? 
Or more locally, things like the opening of the Chunnel? Vaclav Havel's ascendancy to the Czech presidency? The election of Obama? Whatever you might think of his policies, the election of a black person to the presidency of a country with a history like that of the US was amazing.
A rose is as real as a rat. There are just fewer of them.

@SP

I get you - you make a few good points.

At the same time, however, I must admit I quite enjoyed the puzzle and found it challenging - it was not properly Saturday-hard, maybe, but it definitely made me sweat in places, especially in the SW.

Granted, most of my difficulties, as usual, were down to not knowing stuff: I had to rely on crosses for the lentil stew, musical title, ARIEL, LOLA and ETHAN, among other things. Also, I wouldn't be caught dead in a chain eatery, and I know very little about American ones, but if it's a chain in America and starts with an I, it's gotta be IHOP. And so on. So I guess what I liked today was how the arcana were crossed gently enough to not be unsolvable - unlike yesterday, when proper names and abbreviations crossed in several places, forcing me into lookups and puzzle checks.

Had I known the trivia, I would probably have had a Wednesday solving experience, as I guess you did, and you felt cheated.

NEMEAN was an enjoyable gimme. My wife and I visited Nemea on our spring trip to Greece a few years ago and we were enchanted by it. It is located where the mountains of the Peloponnese give way to hills stretching to the Gulf of Corinth. In ancient times, there was no city here, only a sanctuary of Zeus with a nearby stadium, used exclusively in the summer. Today, it is a rural landscape, completely idyllic, full of olive and orange groves, cypress trees, meadows, and fields. The local agiorgitiko wine was quite nice, too.

@Andrzej

That description of Nemea...was surprisingly beautiful!
@SP +1 for "`Precious` person".
@SP never heard of an eraserpen or a leather bar so if the trivia is on your wavelength it was easy but I found it impenetrable

@Francis

Surprisingly... üò¢

@Andrzej
It should be so easy to avoid American chain eateries. My wife and I always preferred the locally-owned and operated diners, pizza counters, home-cooked restaurants. When we travel, we look for such places. Unfortunately, when Big Restaurant, or Big Retail comes to town, it's end of days for these family-owned and operated eateries. That, plus family-owned and operated businesses are not able to pass the torch down to the next generation. This forces either closing the business, or selling to a large conglomerate who "collects" niche markets.
  We just saw our local boat marina being forced to sell to Big Dock, due to lack of a willing recipient of the legacy.

Very nice writeup of your visit to Greece. My wife and I did a Greek Isles cruise last year and were equally enthralled with the beauty and ancient culture of Greece and Turkey. Our only regret is not being to stay at each stop longer than a day. We did manage a 3-day stay in Athens, though we wish our stay in Santorini could have been longer.

@Mishlev
Agreed, why take offense if none was intended.

@J-J Cote

The Blues Brothers did indeed wear fedoras. Pork pie hats have flatter crowns and smaller brims. Buster Keaton, the unparalleled master of silent movie stunts, famously wore a pork pie hat.

@Al  in Pittsburgh,

Think Popeye Doyle in French Connection.
@S.R. speak for yourself - I found it impossible.

@Heidi
Bronchitis is a real nasty. Get well soon.
@Heidi the Legami eraser pens are excellent, as are the Frixion ones.

@Heidi

Huh, I must be in the minority.  I remember the Erasermate as being a truly terrible pen.

@Heidi et al

I have a funny "correction."
I have a "pen" that is constructed with nothing but a tubular "eraser"-- which works on pencil marks.  

I am a big fan/user of FriXion pens, which I refer to as "pens with erasable ink."  I sometimes mark quilts with the pen, using heat from an iron to erase the ink; however, this can leave pale lines if the fabric is dark, so I use it sparingly.
@Becky Or they could bring back the acrostic.
@Becky You're going for Mini Midi Mici! I came, I solved, I conquered!

@Becky

They have that at the end of the year. It only comes out in paper form, which is why I don‚Äôt do it.

@Patrick J.

This made me wonder how much simpler Polish terminology is. ( ) is "nawias" and [ ] "nawias kwadratowy" (kwadratowy means square). I have no idea what the curly thing is called.

@Patrick J. When I was teaching computer science, way way back, I used exactly those three words - parentheses, brackets, and braces. 

What are non-curly braces be then?

@Patrick J.
As an OK boomer, I found that to be generational. The GenY coders used the terms CURLY BRACES or CURLIES quite a lot. They also said SQUARE BRACKETS, also tautological. I would refer to the empty parens as "bowlegs" to tautolize them right back.

@Jerry et al
As a boomer (albeit one who didn't become a programmer till 1985) I say CURLY BRACKETS and had never heard BRACES in this context at all. My problem was rather that PARENTHESES fit too. {} more for set theory in my experience though I did a bit of C around 1995.... And [] mostly for [sic].
@Patrick J. Yeah, I've always found it weird. I always refer to them by their simple names as you do but coworkers definitely call them "curly braces" for some reason.
@spurious have you checked to see if your app needs an update? It showed for me after updating.

@Stephen
A NINE course meal? NINE? That's a hangover in the making without the aperitifs, wine pairings and cocktails.
@Jerry to be fair, most of the courses are tiny

MaryEllen,
My children when quite young would have gotten the joke in the clue, knowing you don't actually have to dress is a particular way to go to a LEATHER BAR, or a lesbian bar, or other similar establishments in our neighborhood. MaryEllen,
Even before first grade, my children had friends with gay parents (to say nothing of having gay neighbors). Some of the local children went to the same board certified pediatrician. It was all quite innocent. Really.
@MaryEllen shoo

MOL,
A leather bar caters to a certain subset of men; you don't need to wear leather to be admitted. There are bars that cater to a certain subset of women; you don't need to wear lipstick to go there. There are also college bars, but a student ID is not required.

@MaryEllen

I may not understand what you are saying. I think innocence is responding to people as people and to couples as couples and not making a big deal out of it. When I've seen parents try to protect innocence by not letting them interact with people they see as "morally" deficient, it has meant the beginning of the destruction of innocence, the adoption of judgmentalness and a sense of moral superiority.
Sure, but I mean their natural state.

@MaryEllen


My parents would have been extremely upset by it. 

I was not able to have kids with my husband, but if I had, we would be totally okay with it. 

After all if I had been able to have kids, they would have had a half sister (my husband's daughter of course) who is married to a woman and they have a beautiful daughter of their own, so our kids would not have blinked at such things from early on. 

How on earth would knowing gay people, or about gay people, ruin a child's innocence!?

MOL,
I did explain, in the first sentence. To expand, a "leather bar" is for certain types of gay men; it doesn't have a "dress requirement." Similarly, a bar favored by "lipstick lesbians" does not require the wearing of make-up. You have lived in college towns; a "college bar" does not require a student ID.

Your husband is thinking only of the One Ring, and even that one was possessed at one time or another by : Sauron, Isildur, Deagol, Smeagol/Gollum, Bilbo Baggins, Frodo Baggins, Tom Bombadil, and Samwise Gamgee (and technically Gandalf for a few moments).

There were 19 other rings of power crafted by Sauron: 
Three for the Elves, possessed by Galadriel, Eldron, Cirdan, and Gandalf.
Seven for the Dwarves, possessed by the leaders of the individual tribes.
Nine for the Kings of Men, who became the Nazgul, including the Witch King of Angmar.

My first exposure to ashiness was when talking with a woman at an outdoor concert when she commented to her daughter that she (the daughter) had had too much sun. I asked her (the mother) what she was seeing that told her that, and she said her daughter was looking ashy. That prompted a conversation about skin care.

What a rewarding job that must have been!  A blessing for you and them!

Getting to know people with different backgrounds and skin colors etc is also such a blessing. I'm trying to refrain from talking about real world things happening right now out here, but I sure wish more people understood that these days...

They're referring to the Midi. There isn't a separate place to discuss the smaller crosswords.
@Mike Oh boy! What do they have instead? Something in Computer assisted design(CAD)?
@Wyra if you click on the ‚Äúi‚Äù link in the midi, it takes you here. If you do it on the mini, it goes to a blank page. Definitely room for improvement.
The fiber called mohair is the hair of Angora goats. The fiber called angora is the hair of Angora rabbits.

@Kathy Glaes

Regardless, it's a fun reset of Bennie and the Jets!

@Lynn Thank you for taking the hit(s). I've a decades long dread of all forms of customer support, and clammy glad-handed chatbots and autoresponders are but the newest wrinkle. The address should still be NYTGames@NYTimes.com They seem to play hide and seek here as to when it appears in the forum. It would be fascinating to hear if you ever get a substantive human response. I'm not holdingy breath.

@B
OK, I'll give it another go. Takes energy to temporarily suspend my disbelief that anything will come of it.

@Lynn

Way to take one for the team!! ‚ò∫Ô∏è

@B
I haven't written often, but I have occasionally gotten a human response, and they have  usually been remarkably unsubstantive.

userLocation: Back in Jays-town. üê¶ Spring at last!
commentBody:
@Bob T.
You have to go through at least two rounds of bot-ƒçrap before you get a supposed human. And I can pretty well guarantee that  that text will be some variant of:

Thank you for taking the time to write us about YOUR PROBLEM. We can understand that YOUR PROBLEM is bothering you and we will see what, if anything, we can do to fix it.

If you write to ask for a follow-up contact, a reference number, or an escalation to a more senior problem-fixer, you get crickets.

It's an excellent example of customer non-service. Ptui!

@Linda Jo
Oh, *that* thing. I had a Pentel Clic when I was taking architectural drawing in high school, but did not know it by that nomenclature. Thanks so much.
@Ciar√°n Yes, apnea is lack of breathing. As in sleep apnea, where individuals have periods of stopped breathing alternating with periods of snoring.

@Ciar√°n
Think of "breathlessness" literally rather than the way we usually use it. As in, no breath.

Lynn,
And this is just the place to report wordplay.

@Barry
I should stop sending complaints about misdirects to the virtual assistant?

Lynn,
I'd look for another way to get in the door.

@Anonymous
Ooohh! 
What a gorgeous, intimidating, empty grid. 
Must  Fill  Out  Now.
üëãüèº
In retrospect, can‚Äôt believe I didn‚Äôt pick up on 54A faster, especially given that I definitely suspected the alliterative aspect‚Ä¶but ain‚Äôt that how it goes sometimes

@Anonymous

Took me more than 80 minutes.

For the top section, I was pretty sure of 17A but didn't catch that they were using his middle initial. I remember him because he was the last presidential candidate my dad said he ever voted FOR (rather than casting his vote because he was against the other guy) until Obama. 

My dad was also a Pogo fan but it took me a very long time to remember the name of that alligator.

I knew the last letter of 10D but when I got the "at least one letter's amiss" the hold-up turned out to be the last letter of 9D. It was my second guess, tho. 

And I had fun the whole time : )

@HeathieJ

Just thought of a cartoon of a funeral home, with a sign that says "Walk ins, welcome!"

@HeathieJ
Feather Bars!
In my "before times," I have been to many a gay nightlife spot, where steerhide may have been the dress code, and yet the atmosphere was definitely "feather bar"!
Thank you for making my day!
@HeathieJ And now my bucket list includes an evening whiled away in appropriate attire at a feather bar.

@HeathieJ completely agree wrt 35 down. The system has not designed to post any of my comments pointing out the disingenuousness of their originality argument (very easy to think of other words that started as something innocent but today are utterly verboten), and I think less of everybody involved for both the fill and the refusal to post my complaint and thus, I must assume, others' complaints.

@HeathieJ
I'm surprised, as I think of you and I as usually being on the same page/wavelength. I got a real kick out of that phrase the first time I heard it--I thought it nicely filled a spot in the language for a particular

@HeathieJ
ack. decided to cancel halfway through typing and accidentally slipped and hit the submit button. I just thought it concisely conveyed a certain kind of performative childish over-reaction to a perceived slight. I did get a kick out of seeing it in the grid, and I'm sorry you did not.

@Bob T.

Aw, no worries. I'm not mad or clutching pearls or anything, it just kind of weirds me out a bit. Cringy as the kids used to say. I can be very visual with words, and sometimes have kind of weird reactions

I also have a big problem with "I want to pick your brain." If it's someone I know fairly well, I always respond with "Keep your dirty mits out of my brain! I'll tell you anything I know, but keep your ice picks to yourself!" Har!! üßä‚õèÔ∏è

Just a weird sort of visceral feeling that I get.  ü§∑‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è

I'm glad you accidentally submitted! ‚ò∫Ô∏è I always appreciate hearing other perspectives!

Bill,
The Eagle? How about the Anvil?

@BA
How embarassing!
Well, I knew it wasn't the Mineshaft or the Lure, and I was (w)racking my brain trying to remember other names--I told you it was the "before times." 
Although, back in the BT, I would regularly visit Boston, Washington, Toronto, Montreal, and of course Chicago and San Francisco, as part of the "circuit," somehow I always missed NYC--the number of times I've been there as an adult could be counted on Frodo's right hand.

Bill,
None of us remember everything word for word from BT. I know it the same way I know a lot of places I've never frequented; it's in the neighborhood. And I've been in the neighborhood since deliveries to the Meatpacking District  were made by refrigerated car on the High Line.

Lynn,
We can afford it because we paid off the mortgage on our co-op apartment more than 20 years ago.

@Kristin thank you for such a helpful illustration of the clue! 

One of my favourite things about the NYT crossword is that you never know quite what you're going to get ‚Äì some entries reference 1950s television, others are internet neologisms, and yet others draw from French, Russian, or Chinese. Some are serious staples of crossword history; some are tongue-in-cheek, irreverent debuts. In a puzzle whose catalogue includes BOOBOOs and ORGYs, I have to ask: what do you believe to be the standard of worthiness for inclusion here?

@Cas I agree with you, and I don't have a problem with any of those examples you mentioned. This particular phrase is most commonly used derogatorily/as an insult, and is (I think) widely understood to connote something other than spanking. I think it's the combination of those two factors that, to me, should be disqualifying. It's okay if we disagree on that point though.
@Serena came here to say this!

@Serena I saw a large number of posts regarding 35D, and I must admit my ignorance. I have heard this phrase used in East Texas since 2016, and it wasn't used in a derogatory context. But, thank you for voicing your observation. Some of us never considered that it could be offensive.
